sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

revisionDesc.change: adopted Carolyn Black edits and additions

list.item: Edward Deuoraxe de Castell Bromwiche in Comitate warwici admissus est in societatem huius hospitij nostri ij die ffebruarij anno supradicto Henricus Princeps.
ffranciscus Dethicke de admiss de created from d of cancelled admiss with e written over m Newhall in Comitate Darbye admissus est in societatem huius hospitij eodem die Henricus Princeps.
Guillelmus Poape de Roxton in Comitate Oxoniæ admissus est in societatem huius hospitij eodem die

item.del: ffranciscus East de in Comitate Cantabrigiæ admissus est in societatem hospitij nostri eodem die

list.item: extra hospitium pro in plena pencione tentus decimo octavo die Iunij Anno 38 Elizabeth Regine: Henricus Princeps Purpoole.
Edward Devereux of Bromwich Castle in the county of Warwick has been admitted into the society of this our Inn on 2 February in the abovesaid year. (signed) Henry, prince (of Purpoole)
Francis Dethicke of New Hall in Derbyshire has been admitted into the society of this Inn on the same day in the abovesaid year. (signed) Henry, prince (of Purpoole)
William Pope of Roxton in the county of Oxford has been admitted into the society of this Inn on the same day.

Outside the Inn [Francis East of (blank) in the county of Cambridge has been admitted into the society of our Inn on the same day.] He (is) kept outside the Inn in full pension on 18 June in the thirty-eighth year (of the reign) of Queen Elizabeth. (signed) Henry, Prince of Purpoole

note.ab: Prominent among those granted honorary admission by Henry Helmes, Prince of Purpoole, were John Lyly (p 125, l.7), almost certainly the playwright, and John Spencer (p 125, l.14), lord mayor of London (see ODNB for both men). A pane of stained glass commemorating Spencer’s membership survives in the hall of Gray’s Inn

list.item:
Ihoannes Cooke & Edwardus Cooke de Westminster admissius sunt in societatem huius hospitij xxv die Decembris anno Elizabeth Regine xxx vij
Henry Princeps Purpoole

Phillippus Waintworth de Cotton in Comitate Suffolciæ Anthonius ffletcher de Cockermouth in Comitate Comberlandiae Thomas Thomkins de Civitate Londini Ihoannes Lillie de Civitate Londini Thomas Smith de frammingham in Comitate Suffolk admissi sunt in societatem huius hospitij die & anno supradictis
Henry Princeps Purpoole
John Cooke and Edward Cooke of Westminster were admitted into the society of this Inn on 25 December in the thirty-seventh year (of the reign) of Queen Elizabeth. Henry, Prince of Purpoole

Philip Wentworth of Cotton in the county of Suffolk, Anthony Fletcher of Cockermouth in the county of Cumberland, Thomas Thomkins of the city of London, John Lyly of the city of London, (and) Thomas Smyth of Framingham in the county of Suffolk were admitted into the society of this Inn on the abovesaid day and (in the abovesaid) year. Henry, Prince of Purpoole
Iohannes Spencer Maior ciuitatis Londoni admissus est in societatem huius Hospitij sexto die Ianuarij. Anno dominae Reginae Elizabethae 37o Henrie Helmes Princeps Purpool

John Spencer, mayor of the city of London, has been admitted into the society of this Inn on 6 January in the thirty-seventh year (of the reign) of the lady, Queen Elizabeth. Henry Helmes, Prince of Purpoole

note.ab: Prominent among those granted honorary admission by Henry Helmes, Prince of Purpoole, were John Lyly, almost certainly the playwright, and John Spencer, lord mayor of London (see ODNB for both men). A pane of stained glass commemorating Spencer’s membership survives in the hall of Gray’s Inn.

note.del: Henricus Princeps absque fine duranti festo

Iohannes Butler miles de Woodhall in comitatu Hartfordiæ admissus est in hanc societatem die & anno supradictis
Gulielmus Button miles de London admissus est vt supra

Thomas Talbot de Risly in Comitatu Bedfordiae admissus vt supra

note.del: (Admitted) without fine during the feast. Prince Henry (of Purpoole)

item.del: Thomas Wright of London, esquire, has been admitted 26 December by Henry II, Prince (of Purpoole) 1617.

list.item: Similarly: Edward Aschan, esquire, of Cotton in the county of Lincoln, admitted 26 December, by Henry II, prince (of Purpoole), 1617.
list.note: (Admitted) without fine. Henry, Prince of Purpoole
list.item: Samuel Tryon of London, knight, has been admitted 29 December by Henry II, Prince (of Purpoole), 1617.
Huntingdon Hastings Corney, of Pickering in the county of York, esquire, has been admitted 29 December by Henry II, Prince (of Purpoole), 1617.
Thomas Lee, esquire, of London has been admitted 30 December by Henry II, Prince (of Purpoole) 1617.
Thomas Woode, knight, gentleman of the king’s chamber, has been admitted 30 December by Henry II, Prince (of Purpoole) 1617.
list.note: Henry, Prince of Purpoole. (Admitted) without a fine.
list.item: Gervase Elwes, esquire, of London in the county of Middlesex, has been admitted 4 January by Henry II, Prince (of Purpoole), 1617.
John Smyth, knight, of Leeds in the county of Kent, has been admitted 4 January by Henry II, Prince (of Purpoole), 1617.
list.note: Henry, Prince of Purpoole. (Admitted) without a fine
list.item: Tobias Wright, son and heir of Richard Wright of Lewknor in the county of Oxford, has been admitted into the society of this Inn 5 January, in the first year (of the reign) of Henry II, (Prince of Purpoole), 1617.
list.note: Henry, Prince of Purpoole. (Admitted) without a fine
list.item: Edward Yelverton, esquire, of London, has been admitted into the society of this Inn on the day and year aforesaid. |
Esmé́ Stuart, Lord Aubigny, has been admitted into this society on the abovesaid day and year.
Arthur Ingram, knight, secretary, in the presence of the president and council of the lord king in the northern parts, has been admitted into this society on the abovesaid day and year.
John Butler, knight, of Woodhall in the county of Hertford, has been admitted into this society on the abovesaid day and year.
William Button, knight, of London, has been admitted as above.
Dudley Digges, knight, of Chilham in the county of Kent, has been admitted as above.
John Pakington, esquire, son and heir of John Pakington, knight, has been admitted as above.
Richard Johnson, son and heir of Richard Johnson, has been admitted into this society as above.
Thomas Talbot of Riseley in the county of Bedford admitted as above.

note.ab: Henry, Prince of Purpoole of Gray’s Inn for 1617–18, called Henry the second (Henry Helmes of 1594–5 becoming retrospectively Henry the first) was Henry Yelverton: see below, endnote to STC: 17944a.5 single sheet verso col 2. Sir Dudley Digges was admitted to Gray’s Inn a second time, just prior to 8 November 1630, presumably because this admission by the Prince of Purpoole was not deemed sufficiently regular (Fletcher (ed), Pension Book, p 299, n 1).

The unnamed Gray’s Inn Prince of Purpoole for 1617–18 was ‘Henry Yelverton, second son of William Y., of Rougham, Norfolk, Esq.’ He was admitted 2 February 1611/12 and knighted (as ‘of Gray’s Inn’) 23 February 1617/18 at Newmarket (Foster, Register, p 129; and Wm. A. Shaw, The Knights of England, vol 2 (London, 1906), 167). For ‘Henry the first,’ and for Edward Smyth of Lincoln’s Inn, see Introduction, p xx.
